author: @bizzaaach
text: A "Hadarmard sandwich" on one qubit is a change of basis, since the Hadamard transformation has order 2. Ie. For unitary U, HUH = HUH^-1 gives the matrix for U in the Hadamard basis.

text: Not sure you already get the correct terminology, but what you call certain qubits, I believe you are referring to when the qubit is an eigenstate of the z-component of the spin, I mean, it is an eigenstate of the S_z operator. In simple words, the vector in on the z-axis, and the uncertain qubits it has a projection to the z-axis only.

author: @VincentBILLET26
text: if you use a X gate, after a Hadamard Gate, it won't change the bloch vector, of course (if it is on the X axis)... BUT it changes the phases, which is really important for many quantum algorithms. For instance, if you create a circuit XH, it will give you the same bloch vector ( |-> ) as XHX circuit, but with opposite phases for |0> and |1>.
